chapter.title: General information
chapter.para: Welcome to the user manual of Fast Track 4.0.0.

Fast Track is a cross-platform application designed to track multiple animals in video recording. Stable versions of the software are available for Linux, Mac and Windows. The development version and the source code can be downloaded at https://git.benjamin-gallois.fr.
Two main features are implemented in the software:

listitem.para: An automatic tracking algorithm that can detect and track objects (conserving the objects identities across the video recording).
A manual review of the tracking where errors can be corrected rapidly and easily.

section.title: Download
section.para: Stable versions of Fast Track are released for Linux (as AppImage), Mac (as dmg) and Windows (installer). The development version is accessible from source and can be compiled for Linux, Mac, and Windows (see the developer guide for more information).

listitem.para: Stable versions:
Download the right file for your system at http://fishytracking.benjamin-gallois.fr/download.html.
The development version:
Please refers to the developer guide at http://fishytracking.benjamin-gallois.fr/API/index.html.
For Windows:
Execute the installer and follow the provided instructions.
For Linux:
Allow FastTrack.AppImage to be executed:
Right click on the AppImage file.
Click on Properties.
Click on Permissions.
Tick Allow executing file as program.
For Mac:
Double click on the dmg file.
Drag the application from the dmg window into the Applications folder.

section.title: Image sequence
section.para: Fast Track can only analyze image sequences. The images must follow the zeroes padding naming convention (name00000.extension, name00001.extension, name00002.extension â€¦). pgm, png, jpeg, jpg, tiff, tif, bmp, dib, jpe, jp2, webp, pbm, ppm, sr, ras, tif image formats are supported.
If you have a recording in a video format, you need to convert it into an image sequence:

listitem.para: For Linux, Windows, and MacOs in command lines:
Install ffmpeg.
In a terminal type: ffmpeg -i video.webm image-%03d.png
For Linux, Windows, and MacOs in graphical:
Use Handbrake: https://handbrake.fr/ or ImageJ.

section.title: Start an analysis
section.para: How to add image sequences to analyze?

listitem.para: Click on the (1) open folder button to select a folder where an image sequence to analyze is stored. The path can be directly pasted or dragged into the (2) path bar.

(Optional) Click on the (3) open background image button to select a background image. If no background image is selected, the program will compute a background image by averaging the selected number of images (see ) . The path can be directly pasted or dragged into the (4) background path bar.
Click on the (6) Add path button to add the path into the analysis queue visibles in the (7) paths table.
The added path is now visible in the (7) paths table.
If necessary you can remove a path from the (7) paths table by clicking on the path, it will become highlighted in blue, and by clicking on the (5) Remove path button.
Start the analysis by clicking on the (8) start tracking button. The analysis can not be paused or stopped until the queue is empty.

caption.para: 1: Open folder button. 2: Path bar. 3: Open background image. 4: Background path bar. 6: Add path button. 5 Remove path button. 7: Paths table. 8: Start tracking button.

section.title: See current analysis
section.para: The display panel shows the current analysis process by displaying the binary image (1) and the grayscale image (2). Note that the tracking can be extremely fast, to review the tracking please see .

caption.para: 1: Open folder button. 2: Path bar. 3: Open background image. 4: Background path bar. 6: Add path button. 5 Remove path button. 7: Paths table. 8: Start tracking button.

section.title: Change parameters
section.para: The tracking parameters can be changed in the Parameters panel. Note that the number of objects can't be changed during analysis.

We recommend finding a set of parameters by changing parameters one by one and controlling their effects in the display panel. When an optimal set of parameters is found, restart the analysis. An interactive help to determine some parameters is available by clicking on the help button (1).

row.entry: Dilates the image. Sets to 0 for no dilatation.
Sets to yes to activate registration.
Sets to yes if objects are dark on light background. Sets to no if objects are light on dark background.
Bottom corner y coordinate of the region of interest. Sets to 0 for keeping the full image.
Bottom corner x coordinate of the region of interest. Sets to 0 for keeping the full image.
Top corner y coordinate of the region of interest. Sets to 0 for keeping the full image.
Top corner x coordinate of the region of interest. Sets to 0 for keeping the full image.
1 to number of images in the image sequences
The number of images averaged to compute the background.
Size of the arrow in the tracking display.
The maximum assignment distancei in pixels. Only objects that have moved less than this value between two images are considered for the matching phase.
Closer to one the cost function used in the matching phase will be more sensitive to change in distance, closer to zero it will be more sensitive to change in direction.
The maximal change in orientation in degrees of an object between two consecutive images.
The maximal displacement in pixels of an object between two consecutive images.
The part of the object used for the matching. 0: head, 1: tail, 2: full body.
The threshold value (0 to 255) to separate objects from the background.
The minimal size of an object in pixels.
The maximal size of an object to in pixels.
The number of objects to track.

section.title: Interactive parameters help
section.para: A semi-automatic help is provided to help the user to set up the size of tracked objects. Open the Setup Help window by clicking the (1) help button.

listitem.para: Open an image by clicking on the Open image button.
Select a typical object by clicking and dragging the mouse to enclose the object in the green rectangle.
Click on the Crop button to crop the image.
Threshold the object by displacing the slider.
Tick/untick the Invert tick-box to have a white object on a black background.
Click on the Compute button to display the recommended maximal and minimal area parameters.

figure.title: Binarize and compute the optimal parameters

section.title: Tracking review
section.para: The replay panel allows the user to open and see the result of a tracking analysis and to correct the tracking if errors are detected.

caption.para: 1: Open folder button. 2: Folder path bar. 3: Reload button. 4: Save button. 5: Next occlusion. 6: Previous occlusion. 7: Display screen. 8: Draw ellipse options. 9: Draw arrow options. 10: Display number. 11: Draw trajectory trace. 12: Size option. 13: Fps box. 14: Play button. 15: First object selected. 16: Second object selected. 17: Swap button. 18: Keyboard shortcuts help. 19: Display cursor.

listitem.para: Click on the (1) open folder button to open a folder where an image sequence previously analyzed is stored (if no tracking data are detected, the software will display only the image sequence). Be careful to open the image sequence folder and not the tracking_result folder. You can also past or drag the folder's path to the (11) path edit bar.
The image sequence is displayed in the (6) display screen and can be played by clicking on the (5) play button or by moving the (7) play cursor. The frame rate can be chosen with the (7) fps box.
You can change the display options with (2) options boxes.

section.title: Correct errors
section.para: To correct a tracking error (mismatching between two objects during the tracking):

listitem.para: Get to the frame where the error occurs:
By playing the image sequence with the (19) display cursor and the (14) play button and visually identify errors.
By clicking on (5) and (6) occlusion buttons to go to the previous and the next occlusion event where mismatchings are the most probable to occurs.
Left click on the first object or select the number of the first object in the (15) swap box. The box displays the number and the color of the selected object.
Left click on the second object or select the number of the second object in the (16) swap box. The box displays the number and the color of the selected object.
Right click on the (7) display screen or click on the (17) swap button to swap the two objects from the image displayed to the end of the image sequence.

section.title: Correct rapidly a tracked image sequence
section.para: Mouse and keyboard shortcuts are provided to rapidly correct errors. The user can move inside the image sequence and review all occlusion events with the keyboard shortcuts and correct the tracking by swapping objects with the mouse.
For AZERTY keyboard:

listitem.para: Next image: Z
Previous image: S
Next occlusion: Q
Previous occlusion: D
Play: Space

section.para: For QWERTY keyboard:

listitem.para: Next image: W
Previous image: S
Next occlusion: A
Previous occlusion: D
Play: Space

section.para: Mouse shortcuts:

listitem.para: Left click to select objects.
Right click to swap objects.

section.title: Save a tracking movie
section.para: The result of a tracking can be saved in a video file. Select the display options and the frame rate desired and click on the (8) save button. The movie will be saved in a .avi container with the MJPEG codec. In case of errors, check that you have the MJPEG codec available on your system.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: When an analysis is started, Fast Track creates a folder named Tracking_Result containing:

listitem.para: A text file tracking.txt containing the tracking data (in the frame of reference of the full image with the origin in the top left corner).
A text file parameters.txt containing the set of parameters saves at the beginning of the analysis, changes during the analysis are not saved.

row.entry: The x-coordinate of the center of mass of the head ellipse. The frame of reference origin is in the top left corner.
The y-coordinate of the center of mass of the head ellipse. The frame of reference origin is in the top left corner.
The orientation of the head ellipse in radians (between 0-2*pi, no negative angle).
The x-coordinate of the center of mass of the tail ellipse. The frame of reference origin is in the top left corner.
The y-coordinate of the center of mass of the tail ellipse. The frame of reference origin is in the top left corner.
The orientation of the tail ellipse in degrees (between 0-360, no negative angle).
The x-coordinate of the center of mass of the body ellipse. The frame of reference origin is in the top left corner.
The y-coordinate of the center of mass of the body ellipse. The frame of reference origin is in the top left corner.
The orientation of the body ellipse in degrees (between 0-360, no negative angle).
The major axis length of the head ellipse.
The minor axis length of the head ellipse.
The excentricity of the head ellipse.
The major axis length of the tail ellipse.
The minor axis length of the tail ellipse.
The excentricity of the tail ellipse.
The major axis length of the body ellipse.
The minor axis length of the body ellipse.
The excentricity of the body ellipse.

section.title: The tracking.txt file
section.para: The file tracking.txt can be opened with any spreadsheet softwares or common analysis packages like Python and Matlab.

section.title: Opening tracking.txt with a spreadsheet software
section.para: Open the file with your favorite spreadsheet sofware, it would normally autodectect the delimiter, if no, select Tab as the delimiter.

figure.title: Opening tracking.txt with a spreadsheet software

textobject.phrase: Opening tracking.txt with a spreadsheet software

caption.para: Opening tracking.txt with a spreadsheet software.

figure.title: Opening tracking.txt with a spreadsheet software

textobject.phrase: Opening tracking.txt with a spreadsheet software

caption.para: Opening tracking.txt with a spreadsheet software.

section.title: Opening tracking.txt with Python
section.para: The file tracking.txt can be opened with Python using the Pandas library: pandas.read_csv("tracking.txt", delimiter='\t').

section.title: Opening tracking.txt with Matlab
section.para: The file tracking.txt can be opened with Matlab using the command: data = readtable('tracking.txt', 'Delimiter', '\t').

chapter.title: For developers
chapter.para: A complete API and developer documentation is available. It can be generated for the latest version of Fast Track by executing ./generateDocumentation.sh. A folder Documentation is created with the developer documentation.

chapter.title: Performance
chapter.para: The performance can vary with the selected parameters. Registration and dilatation can cause a loss of 50% in performance. The number of objects influences the performance as the cube of the object number.
